awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Enabling a strong DKIST start - The Magnetic Structure of Solar Filaments
awd_abstract_narration:
On the Sun, magnetic fields are found in both active and quiet large structures forming and erupting from the Sun's surface called solar filaments. The investigators propose to make and study a large data set that measures the magnetic field inside these filaments, including both erupting and non-erupting configurations, of both active and quiet solar filaments. These studies will cover all steps in a solar filament's lifetime, from formation to stability to eruption. Obtaining the complete magnetic field data set required to study solar filaments is only now possible using a medium-sized telescope equipped with special instrumentation, now available to the investigators.  The investigators will be ready to study observations of the solar filaments made at greater resolutions by the new Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope when it begins operation.  This project supports the mission of the NSF by promoting our understanding of magnetic field structure and activity at the Sun. The investigators will include a graduate student and a post-doctoral associate to support the research and learn data analysis techniques.

Magnetism exists as linear, sheared structures that allows for filament formation; the lack of cross-field drift in the structure stabilizes the filament plasma from thermalization and collapse; and only magnetism can rapidly rearrange structure and result in eruption. Three specific science questions will be addressed: What is the magnetic field configuration of forming solar filaments?  What is the magnetic field configuration of stable solar filaments?  What is the magnetic field configuration of a filament prior to eruption?  To address these, the investigators set three specific objectives: Define and obtain ten spectropolarimetric sequences in the He I absorption line at 10830A, in order to study filament formation. Classify solar filament structure by producing a pipeline to reduce, analyze, and interpret these spectropolarimetric data. Identify those magnetic configurations prior to a loss of filament stability. Data analysis requires the training of personnel in running and expanding the HAZEL inversion code into pipeline in order to study the magnetic structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As Solar Cycle 25 begins to put on a show of solar flares and Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs), scientists from New Mexico State University, in collaboration with the National Solar Observatory and other partners, used the Dunn Solar Telescope (DST) to observe precursors to a CME eruption. The team observed subtle temperature and motion changes in a filament leading up to its eruption over a two day period. The ability to detect the precursor phase of a filament eruption could provide scientists with a whole extra day to predict the arrival of CMEs and improve space weather prediction models, almost doubling the lead time on CME predictions!

Filaments, or twisted plasma suspended in the Sun’s magnetic field, vary by nature. Some form quickly and explode into space, while others linger for days to months until they slowly erupt or dissipate back to the Sun’s surface. The particles and magnetic field of an erupting filament become a CME, and if it’s Earth-directed, will only take a matter of 18-36 hours to arrive as space weather events. 

On May 30, 2017, Dr. Shuo Wang led a team of scientists at the DST as they observed the initial phase of a filament eruption. Over two days, they watched as the filament went through interesting temperature and motion changes before its explosive departure from the Sun’s magnetic grasp. 

These images show the evolution of the filament eruption between 00:06 UT and 18:56 UT on 2017 May 30 with a changing cadence of 2–10 minutes. The duration of the animation is seven seconds. Credit: NASA SDO/ “Velocities of an Erupting Filament,” Shuo Wang et al 2022 ApJ 926 18.

On the first day of observations, the team utilized the DST’s Facility Infrared Spectropolarimeter (FIRS) to study the filament. They saw a relatively quiet Sun as the filament faded out in intensity, yet its temperature increased. Spectral data revealed a slow rising phase of the filament before its detectable position changes. The evolution of the filament’s velocity showed a smooth curve, confirmed with other data sources, indicating that the filament was becoming unstable gradually and gaining momentum slowly. The evolution continued into the next day when the team witnessed the filament’s final escape from the Sun. Observations collected from other ground and space-based sources with high spatial resolution, spectral resolution, and temporal cadence concluded sufficient evidence of the erupting process. 

The conclusion from this study is exciting for the future of space weather prediction models. This study demonstrates the importance of understanding the chromosphere. Chromospheric spectral data has the potential to play a key role in identifying the precursors of a filament eruption or CME. Combined with magnetic field information inferred from spectropolarimeter data, the likes of which will be obtained by U.S. National Science Foundation’s Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope, space weather models can be refined to forecast the impact and estimated time of arrival of Earth-directed CMEs. We may see improved Aurora predictions, too!

There are still a lot of open questions about solar filaments and other solar phenomena waiting to be answered. With the NSF’s Inouye Solar Telescope science observations started in Feb. 2022, the solar community is going to give everything on the Sun, including filaments, a physical check up – interesting scientific discoveries about the Sun are on their way!

Recognition for contributions to this study includes New Mexico State University, NSF, NSO, KU Leuven, Catholic University of America, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, University College London, and California State University Northridge.
